original_data.question: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 10-day history of unsteady gait, frequent falls, and twitching of the extremities. Physical examination shows bilateral saccadic eye movement in all directions and brief, involuntary muscle contractions of the trunk and limbs. There is an ill-defined, nontender mass in the upper right abdomen. He undergoes surgical resection of the tumor. Histopathologic examination of this mass is most likely to show which of the following?

options.A: Numerous immature lymphocytes in a starry sky pattern
options.B: Abortive glomeruli and tubules in a spindle cell stroma
options.C: Small blue cells arranged in rosettes around a central neuropil
options.D: Hepatocytes in fetal and embryonic stages of differentiation

model_response:
The answer is D: Hepatocytes in fetal and embryonic stages of differentiation. The clinical features described are those of a malignant tumor of the nervous system, probably a neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood outside the CNS. It arises from neural crest tissue of the sympathetic nervous system, from the orbit to the pelvis. The tumor is composed of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm. Foci of mature ganglion cells are present in 50% of tumors, and these areas are more likely to be found in the less-differentiated tumors. Foci of glial cells are also found in many tumors, and the presence of rosettes, best seen with silver stains, is a feature of the Ewing tumor. Neuroblastoma is a disease of early childhood, with 90% of patients presenting before 5 years of age. The most common sites of metastases are bone, bone marrow, liver, and subcutaneous tissue. The prognosis is related to the age of the patient at diagnosis, the stage of the disease, and the degree of differentiation of the tumor. The most useful prognostic marker is the amplification of the MYCN (N-myc) gene found on chromosome 2. The more neuroblasts present in the tumor, the more likely it is to metastasize and the worse the prognosis for the patient. The other choices are features of other childhood malignancies.Diagnosis: Neuroblastoma

### GENERAL EXPLANATION

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood outside the CNS. It arises from neural crest tissue of the sympathetic nervous system, from the orbit to the pelvis. The tumor is composed of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm. Foci of mature ganglion cells are present in 50% of tumors, and these areas are more likely to be found in the less-differentiated tumors. Foci of glial cells are also found in many tumors, and the presence of rosettes, best seen with silver stains, is a feature of the Ewing tumor. Neuroblastoma is a disease of early childhood, with 90% of patients presenting before 5 years of age. The most common sites of metastases are bone, bone marrow, liver, and subcutaneous tissue. The prognosis is related to the age of the patient at diagnosis, the stage of the disease, and the degree of differentiation of the tumor. The most useful prognostic marker is the amplification of the MYCN (N-myc) gene found on chromosome 2. The more neuroblasts present in the tumor, the more likely it is to metastasize and the worse the prognosis for the patient. The other choices are features of other childhood malignancies.

### CLINICAL CORRELATION

Neuroblastoma is a disease of early childhood, with 90% of patients presenting before 5 years of age. The most common sites of metastases are bone, bone marrow, liver, and subcutaneous tissue. The prognosis is related to the age of the patient at diagnosis, the stage of the disease, and the degree of differentiation of the tumor. The most useful prognostic marker is the amplification of the MYCN (N-myc) gene found on chromosome 2. The more neuroblasts present in the tumor, the more likely it is to metastasize and the worse the prognosis for the patient.

###PATHOLOGIC FEATURES

Grossly, neuroblastomas are soft, friable, gray-white tumors that often contain calcifications and areas of hemorrhage or necrosis. On microscopic examination, the tumors are composed of small round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm. Foci of mature ganglion cells are present in 50% of tumors, and these areas are more likely to be found in the less-differentiated tumors. Foci of glial cells are also found in many tumors. The occurrence of a single contraction or a series of contractions of a muscle.
The farthest or outermost projections of the body, such as the HAND and FOOT.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
An abrupt voluntary shift in ocular fixation from one point to another, as occurs in reading.

Unstriated and unstriped muscle, one of the muscles of the internal organs, blood vessels, hair follicles, etc. Contractile elements are elongated, usually spindle-shaped cells with centrally located nuclei. Smooth muscle fibers are bound together into sheets or bundles by reticular fibers and frequently elastic nets are also abundant. (From Stedman, 25th ed)

The superior portion of the abdomen.
The surgical removal of an organ or a part of an organ.
New abnormal growth of tissue. Malignant neoplasms show a greater degree of anaplasia and have the properties of invasion and metastasis, compared to benign neoplasms.
The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
